title: Do dams destroy rivers? | Environment | The Guardian

text: an interesting late perspective from mike muller of the university of the witwatersrand .
indeed , dams do change the world and its natural environment .
so do cities , roads , airports , chemical industries and agriculture .
in general , we can say that people change their environment .
the richer they are , the more change they induce .
in the course of that , they often destroy species ; they also create species , but that is not often measured or mentioned .
the notion that some static measure of biodiversity is good and any change is bad is not substantiated by natural history .
as an example , sedimentation as a process is the base of geology , many millennia old , many thousands of metres deep .
so the irn 's latest database is simply that : - a collection of data ( of variable quality ) with no inherent information about whether what is happening is good or bad .
what we need to take from this debate is the realisation that we now live in an anthropocene world , whose form is increasingly structured and sustained through human decision .
we can take deliberate decisions about what kind of world we want to live in .
but that we is not a small group of north american environmentalists and their friends .
it is local and larger communities , taking decisions through their own institutions at different levels and not trying to impose their value sets on others . ''

documents.title: my verdict
text: ultimately dams change rivers .
the degree to which they change and the negative impacts on humans and nature depend on how large they are , how they are built and managed and where they are located .
international rivers ' interactive presentation compellingly highlights the avalanche of dams in production , especially in the developing world .
the biodiversity alarm bells are ringing because developing countries are , well , less developed .
therefore they have some of the least impacted river basins .
the ten least fragmented river systems found by the study were all located in developing countries .
five in south america , two in china and africa and one in southeast asia .
these are also mainly tro or subtro rivers , meaning the number of species at risk is increased .
proposed dams ( red dots ) in the mekong basin , one of the least fragmented major river systems in the world .

rivers this opens up that most fraught of environmental debates - what right does the north , with it 's previously degraded environment and the cosy riches made from its destruction , have to tell the south that it must develop with ecological caution ?
some commentators argued today that the benefits that hydroelectricity brings to communities - cheap , clean power , jobs , tax etc - outweigh the ecological and social damage done .
there is really no way to conclusively answer this question except on a dam by dam basis .
most people seem to accept that there are dams which represent best practice and can have a limited impact .
but the results from international rivers ' database highlight one important fact - most dams are not best practice .
colin thorne , a professor of geography at nottingham university says the short answer is yes '' dams do destroy rivers as ecosystems .
many of the dams built during the 20th century have proven to be river killers .
examples are numerous and notorious . ''
however he also notes the positive impact dams have had in reducing the sum of human misery and encouraging development .

for example , the drought in the horn of africa was a disaster that cost the lives of millions , but the high assam dam spared egypt from a drought that would have been truly catastrophic , '' says thorne .
many of the dams built in the last century were poorly designed and many are now in the process of being removed .
he says the evidence so far is that nature bounces back surprisingly well after dam removal .
the good news is that nature is not only more vulnerable to dams than was realised , it 's also more resilient than we thought .
so maybe the destruction of a river by damming it is n't terminal . ''
he notes that dam building is no longer de rigueur in the west and that vigorous river restoration industries have emerged in europe , australia , new zealand and the usa .
in the us the bureau of reclamation no longer builds dams , but spends more of its time removing them .
but in the developing world , dam building is still booming , while china is finances a large amount of the new construction that threaten river systems in africa and south east asia .
consequently , the question i think is prescient is not whether dams destroy rivers , but whether it is possible to build dams that do n't destroy rivers ?

the short answer is , 'no ' , but the longer answer is , 'well , it may be possible to build dams that damage the river but avoid destroying it , provided they are designed carefully and operated responsibly ' . ''
thorne says there is an unavoidable trade off between the benefits dams bring and the harm they do .
he says the pragmatic approach is to recognise that dams are going to be built because they drive development and generate money .
this makes it imperative to understand the effect of dams on ecosystems and people and apply best practice to limit the damage done to the river .
dr simon gosling from nottingham university has followed up his earlier comments to address some questions about the carbon impacts of dam construction .
a number of the quotes and references today point out the importance of good management when it comes to dam construction and it 's worth reiterating that here .
an interesting study was conducted in the three gorges reservoir area between 2000-2010 .
this period was chosen to demonstrate the before-and-after effects of construction of the dam .

the authors of the study analysed remotely sensed satellite data and they noted that over this period , total net primary productivity ( npp ; essentially co2 intake by plants during photosynthesis minus co2 release during respiration ) decreased by 8.0 % , largely as a result of population resettlement and land inundation .

however , what the authors also show is that major ecological projects implemented in the region since 1998 played an important role in offsetting the negative impacts of the construction of the dam on npp .
thus the impacts of dam construction can to some extent be abated through appropriate planning and subsequent management . ''
reader dimitri has sent in a link to a new scientist article which argues that the carbon benefits of some hydroelectric projects may be an illusion .
contrary to popular belief , hydroelectric power can seriously damage the climate .
hydroelectric dams produce significant amounts of carbon dioxide and methane , and in some cases produce more of these greenhouse gases than power plants running on fossil fuels .
carbon emissions vary from dam to dam , says philip fearnside from brazil 's national institute for research in the amazon in manaus .
but we do know that there are enough emissions to worry about . ''

in a study to be published in mitigation and adaptation strategies for global change , fearnside estimates that in 1990 the greenhouse effect of emissions from the curuá-una dam in pará , brazil , was more than three-and-a-half times what would have been produced by generating the same amount of electricity from oil .
this is because large amounts of carbon tied up in trees and other plants are released when the reservoir is initially flooded and the plants rot .
then after this first pulse of decay , plant matter settling on the reservoir 's bottom decomposes without oxygen , resulting in a build-up of dissolved methane .
this is released into the atmosphere when water passes through the dam 's turbines .

dam effects have created a lovely interactive graphic of the way in which a river is affected by both poorly and well run hydro projects .
it explains the potential pitfalls and how they can be mitigated .
it 's not clear from this whether the organisation believes the negative effects of a dam can be entirely avoided by good management .

julian jones , from campaign group water 21 , says that scale is the key factor in determining biodiversity impacts of dams .

generally , large scale hydropower incurs excessive losses - whereas small or micro hydropower , sensitively installed and operated can offer very significant biodiversity and economic gains , that could be vital at a local level . ''
he goes on to make the case for small scale hydroelectric power in britain , towards which the government is apparently very resistant .
it makes for an interesting read about an issue i was n't familiar with .
i have posted his comments here .
karl mathiesen ( @ karlmathiesen ) the paraná river basin has 412 dams planned ( red dots ) for construction .

here is a snapshot of some of the information collated by the international rivers team .

total number of dams currently existing and operational in each basin : mississippi 703 dams yangtze 374 dams parana 228 dams danube 184 dams st. lawrence 183 dams average number of dams per 100 kilometers of river length per basin : st. lawrence 3.171 hai ho 2.506 godavari 2.226 uruguay 2.069 yangtze 1.868 highest average river fragmentation per basin : hai ho indus yellow godavari tigris - euphrates average water quality index per basin : hai ho wisla dnepr tigris - euphrates yellow marissa thomas , writing for the guardian , highlights the importance of one of the world 's major rivers , the nile , and the impact of dams on its ecosystems and people .
the nile - which is the longest river in the world - travels through ten countries .
four of these countries are water scarce '' and the river is the primary water source of sudan and egypt .
its basin covers 10 % of the landmass of the african continent .
the international rivers database notes : water experts believe there is not enough water in the river to meet the various irrigation goals of the nile basin nations .
adding to potential water stress , existing large dams have made major changes to the river 's flow , increased evaporation in the system , and have altered important ecosystem functions . ''
more dams are under consideration - especially in ethiopia , which is building africa 's largest hydropower dam , the grand ethiopian renaissance dam on the blue nile .
a photo taken in 2012 of the construction site of the controversial xayaburi dam in laos , which opponents said would adversely affect lower mekong river communities below the dam .
/epa the gibe iii dam under construction in ethiopia 's omo valley .
the government says the dam will boost development .
but critics say ethiopia must also consider the environmental and social impact it will have on some 500,000 people living downstream and at lake turkana in kenya , who rely on the river .
vaughan/afp/getty images workers watch on as the three gorges dam discharges water in yichang , hubei province .
shanghai/reuters

klaas-douwe dijkstra , a zoologist at the naturalis biodiversity center in the netherlands , says his research highlights just how many more species live in flowing rivers than the standing lakes created by dams .
he says around 10 % of animal species inhabit inland waters ( which cover 1 % of the earth 's surface ) .
in the temperate zone , 60 % of these species are restricted to flowing waters .
dijkstra says that in the tro the percentage is probably even higher .

he explains : standing waters contribute less to overall biodiversity because those sites are ty less predictable in time and space : its inhabitants thus tend to be better dispersers and therefore have larger ranges .
river species , on the other hand , often disperse poorly and therefore are unique to a specific river system .
so two rivers are likely to have different species , while two lakes tend to have the same . ''
he says the effect of dams , transforming huge sections of rivers and tributaries from flowing systems to standing has a disproportionate impact on global biodiversity '' .

to summarize , the biodiversity argument is huge because freshwater is so much richer than anything else , and because each river system is unique , like a freshwater island surrounded by an inhospitable sea of land . ''
he says arguments made regarding human benefit is difficult and emotionally charged '' .
but he says the argument that millions of lives can be saved from flooding by dams is difficult to swallow '' .
flooding is as natural and important a phenomenon to river hydrology and ecology as the climatic seasonality that causes it .

personally i feel that if flooding is a problem for human safety , ( temporary ) displacement from areas susceptible to natural flooding seems more humane , than ( permanent ) relocation from areas impacted by damming . ''

dr simon dixon from the university of birmingham makes an excellent point that measuring biodiversity ( ie the raw number of species ) is a misleading way to assess the impact of dams on rivers .
dixon explains : the highest areas of biodiversity on the planet are ty in tro regions and the highest areas of economic development are ty in temperate northern hemisphere climates .

so there is a good chance some of the places that have the most dams per 100km ( the best measure on their database of dam intensity ) in north america , europe and china would have lower biodiversity than the big south american and african rivers with or without the dams .
therefore looking at raw snapshots '' of biodiversity can be misleading and probably a more helpful measure in this context is change in biodiversity post dam-building . ''
if anyone knows of studies on the changing biodiversity in rivers affected by dams , please post links to them in the comments below .
dixon says the percentage of sedimentation trapped upstream is an interesting measure as it can be used to ascertain the effect dams are having on the way the river shapes the lands around it .

there are examples of dams which have reduced sediment supply downstream resulting in rivers scouring the remaining sediment below the dam down to bedrock ( with severe implications for ecosystem health ) , or of rivers which have formerly had multiple channels ( braided ) changing to a single channel rivers with extensive exposed sediment bars/islands .

in addition some rivers deliver fine sediment to floodplains with seasonal flooding which enriches the land for farming , and with reduced sediment supply post dam construction this benefit can be reduced or removed . ''
however he says these effects are not the inevitable result of dam building , rather the result of poor management and planning and can thus be avoided .
there is a great ted conversation from last year on the belo monte dam project in the brazilian amazon which touches on many of the themes being raised here .
commenters were keen to acknowledge the clean electricity benefits of hydroelectricity , however the social and environmental impacts create a difficult moral and policy decision .
many commenters highlighted the large investment required for a new dam and wondered if it should n't be spent on other renewable sources .
one of the participants , noel laporte , said that the location of the dam was an important consideration in deciding whether a project should go ahead .
dams can provide positive and negative benefits to the nearby communities and ecosystems in which they reside .
dams deliver clean energy , water storage and the ability to control floods .
given the right implementation and location dams can have hugely positive effects for a society and have low operational costs .
although some dams can bring positive changes upon construction the plan to build the belo monte dam is a very poor decision .
building a dam in the heart of the amazon creates huge ecosystem destruction and massive land change .
the construction site of a hydroelectric dam along the teles pires river , a tributary of the amazon .
brazil plans to build 254 new dams in the amazon basin .
doce/reuters
emphatically , says professor michael cernea , dams do not destroy rivers '' .
though they do have known negative impacts on rivers ' ecologies .

but humanity at large receives irreplaceable benefits from dams : irrigated agriculture on giant surfaces and more food on all continents ; immense amounts of clean energy ; and year after year dams are literally saving the lives of uncounted millions of people through flood control .
our human species has n't yet created any other technology capable to produce these three categories of macro-benefits , indispensable today for our existence . ''
he says the focus of the international rivers database is on the physical effects of dams on river systems .

but there is another factor to consider , the social effects of displacement due to dam building , which he calls the primary and most serious economic and moral problem with dams on a global scale . ''

dams , however , do have immense destructive impacts , but these are primarily of a social nature : the forced physical and economic displacement of huge cumulative amounts of people to create room for dams and their reservoirs .
a tsunami of dam building is now unfolding in asia , africa , and latin america .

tens of millions of people have been and are forcibly uprooted ; they end up worse off , immediately impoverished , with broken livelihoods ; their poverty and impoverishment is telescoped to the next generation .
this is empirically confirmed by legions of researchers and scholars .

yet despite the indisputable evidence , it is financed and encouraged by many international development agencies and by private sector corporations , often under the banner of poverty reduction '' and public purpose projects '' .
impoverishment by displacement is inevitable , yet it is tolerated , denied or papered over in disingenuous reports . ''
what is your reaction to this comment ?
are the biodiversity impacts of dams of less degree or importance than the social impacts ?
let us know in the comments .
dr simon gosling , associate professor in climate risk at the university of nottingham says the database is broad and helpful .
but the large scale mapping means that local detail is difficult to ascertain .
for this reason it 's important to bear in mind that some of the indicators will vary considerably at the sub-basin scale and so will the correlations . ''
he says a global hydrology modelling performed in 2010 showed dams changed the ways rivers flow during the last century .
these fluvial changes could have had impacts on habitat conditions and the life cycle of organisms , e.g .
food availability and spawning .
the correlations reported in today 's database/map seem to support the impacts inferred in the above study . ''
he warned that dam construction projects should be carefully considered and that climate change could exacerbate their impact .

documents.title: summary of findings
text: the database is really a stunning piece of interactive software .
there 's a lot of excellent information and it 's easy to get lost in exploration .
make sure to have a look through it here .

the major findings from the data , which was collated from geographic databases and dam inventories , were : priority basins for remediation the basins that rank the highest in overall combined fragmentation and lowest in water quality are the hai ho , tigris-euphrates , wisla , dnepr , yellow , danube , godavari , mississippi , indus , and volta basins .

priority basins for preservation the basins that rank the highest in biodiversity , the highest in water quality , and the lowest in fragmentation are the amazon , tocantins , ayeyarwaddy , são francisco , orinoco , paraná , congo , zambezi , yangtze , and mekong basins .
other findings river fragmentation due to dams correlated with poor levels of water quality about 80 % of the time in the basins that were studied .
mercury contamination is high in about 72 % of basins that are the most highly fragmented .
fragmentation has led to high amounts of sediment trapped upstream , in about 61 % of basins .
80 % of basins that have the highest number of dams also have the highest amount of thermal pollution .
this could signify that dams have been built in basins with high existing industrial activity , or dams have served as a driver for industrial activity , or both .
poor levels of water quality are correlated to low levels of species density in 62 % of basins , meaning that fragmentation due to dams is a significant factor in biodiversity loss .
the authors make clear that the findings should be interpreted simply as statistical inferences , not as direct , causal relationships '' .

documents.title: welcome to the eco audit
text: a new database has found links between the declining health of the world great rivers and the dams that break up their natural cycles .
the state of the world 's rivers , an interactive survey of the world 's 50 largest river basins , found almost 6,000 dams ( a fraction of the estimated 50,000 that exist in all rivers on earth ) .
the hai ho , tigris-euphrates and wisla basins were found to have the highest degree of fragmentation .
whereas the amazon , tocantins and ayeyarwaddy were among those highlighted as the most pristine and in desperate need of protection .
the study found correlations between fragmentation by dams and poor water quality , mercury concentrations , sedimentation , thermal pollution and declining biodiversity .
the data was collated by international rivers ( ir ) .
executive director of ir jason rainey said the global perspective showed that rivers worldwide needed greater attention and protection .

the evidence we 've compiled of planetary-scale impacts from river change is strong enough to warrant a major international focus on understanding the thresholds for 'river change ' in the world 's major basins , and for the planet as a whole system . ''
but ir warns that the correlations with poor health are only statistical and further study of individual cases is necessary to understand exactly how dams impact rivers .
across the world thousands more dams are being planned .
in brazil 's paraná and amazon basins there are 666 dams in production .
china plans to build 94 large and 73 small dams on the relatively healthy yangtze .
today , with your help , i 'll be trying to find out more about how these massive interruptions might change and degrade these mighty waterways .
join in the discussion by contributing in the comments below , tweet me or email me .
if you are quoting figures or studies , please provide a link to the original source .
follow me on @ twitterid for updates throughout the day and later i will return with my own verdict .
